sen.j: 賀茂別雷神社（かもわけいかづちじんじゃ）は、京都市北区 (京都市)にある神社である。
sen.e: Kamo-wakeikazuchi-jinja Shrine is located in Kita Ward, Kyoto City.
Kamo-wakeikazuchi-jinja Shrine is located in Kita Ward, Kyoto City.
Kamo-wakeikazuchi-jinja Shrine is located in Kita Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 通称上賀茂神社（かみがもじんじゃ）。
sen.e: It is commonly known as Kamigamo-jinja (Upper Kamo Shrine).
It is commonly known as Kamigamo-jinja Shrine (Upper Kamo Shrine).
It is commonly known as Kamigamo-jinja Shrine (Upper Kamo Shrine).

sen.j: 式内社、山城国一宮、二十二社の一社で、旧社格は官幣大社。
sen.e: It was listed in the Register of Deities (Jinmyocho) of the Engishiki law as one of the ichi-no-miya (primary shrines) of the former Yamashiro province, one of The Twenty-Two Shrines, and was categorized as a Kanpei Taisha (Great Imperial Shrine) under the previous shrine ranking system.

It was a Shikinaisha listed in the Register of Deities (Jimmyocho) of the Engishiki law as one of the ichi-no-miya (primary shrines) of the former Yamashiro province, one of The Twenty-Two Shrines, and was categorized as a Kanpei Taisha (Great Imperial Shrine) under the previous shrine ranking system.

It was a Shikinaisha listed in the Register of Deities (Jimmyocho) of the Engishiki law as one of the ichi-no-miya (primary shrines) of the former Yamashiro province, one of The Twenty-Two Shrines, and was categorized as a Kampei Taisha (Great Imperial Shrine) under the previous shrine ranking system.

sen.j: 賀茂御祖神社（下鴨神社）とともに古代の賀茂氏の氏神を祀る神社であり、賀茂神社（賀茂社）と総称される。
sen.e: Along with Kamomioya-jinja Shrine (Shimogamo-jinja, or 'Lower Kamo Shrine') it enshrines ancient ujigami of the Kamo clan, and the pair generally being referred to as Kamo-jinja (Kamo-sha) and treated as paired shrines.

Along with Kamomioya-jinja Shrine (Shimogamo-jinja Shrine, or 'Lower Kamo Shrine') it enshrines ancient ujigami of the Kamo clan, and the pair generally being referred to as Kamo-jinja Shrine (Kamo-sha) and treated as paired shrines.

Along with Kamomioya-jinja Shrine (Shimogamo-jinja Shrine, or 'Lower Kamo Shrine') it enshrines ancient ujigami of the Kamo clan, and the pair generally being referred to as Kamo-jinja Shrine (Kamo-sha) and treated as paired shrines.

sen.j: 賀茂神社両社の祭事である葵祭で有名である。
sen.e: Both Kamo-jinja Shrines are well known for the Kamo Festival (Aoi-matsuri Festival).
Both Kamo-jinja Shrines are well known for the Kamo Festival (Aoi-matsuri Festival).
Both Kamo-jinja Shrines are well known for the Kamo Festival (Aoi-matsuri Festival).

sen.j: 賀茂氏の祖神である賀茂別雷命（かもわけみかづちのみこと）を祀る。
sen.e: Kamigamo-jinja Shrine enshrines the Kamo clan ancestral deity Kamowakeikazuchi-no-mikoto.
Kamigamo-jinja Shrine enshrines the Kamo clan ancestral deity Kamowakeikazuchi-no-mikoto.
Kamigamo-jinja Shrine enshrines the Kamo clan ancestral deity Kamowakeikazuchi-no-mikoto.

sen.j: 「別雷」は「若雷」の意味で、若々しい力に満ちた雷（神鳴り）の神という意味である。
sen.e: Wakeikazuchi' means 'young thunder' and signifies the god of thunder full youthful energy.
Wakeikazuchi' means 'young thunder' and signifies the god of thunder full youthful energy.
Wakeikazuchi' means 'young thunder' and signifies the god of thunder full youthful energy.

sen.j: 付属施設：西村家別邸
創建については諸説ある。
sen.e: There are numerous theories regarding the establishment of the shrine.
There are numerous theories regarding the establishment of the shrine.
There are numerous theories regarding the establishment of the shrine.

sen.j: 社伝では、神武天皇の御代に賀茂山の麓の御阿礼所に賀茂別雷命が降臨したと伝える。
sen.e: According to legend, Kamowakeikazuchi-no-mikoto descended to the miaresho at the foot of Mt. Mikage-yama during the reign of Emperor Jimmu.
According to legend, Kamowakeikazuchi-no-mikoto descended to the Miaresho at the foot of Mt.Kamo-san during the reign of Emperor Jimmu.
According to legend, Kamowakeikazuchi-no-mikoto descended to the Miaresho at the foot of Mt. Kamo-san during the reign of Emperor Jimmu.

sen.j: 『山城国風土記』逸文では、タマヨリビメ（たまよりひめ）が加茂川の川上から流れてきた丹塗矢を床に置いたところ懐妊し、それで生まれたのが賀茂別雷命で、兄玉依日古（あにたまよりひこ）の子孫である賀茂県主の一族がこれを奉斎したと伝える。
sen.e: The ancient text "Yamashiro no Kuni Fudoki" tells that Tamayorihime became pregnant after placing on her bed a vermillion arrow that flowed down from the upper reaches of Kamo-gawa River, and that when she gave birth to Kamowakeikazuchi-no-mikoto, he was enshrined by the Kamo territorial ruling family of Anitamayorihiko's descenfants.

The ancient text "Yamashiro no Kuni Fudoki" tells that Tamayorihime became pregnant after placing on her bed a vermilion-lacquered arrow that flowed down from the upper reaches of Kamo-gawa River, and that when she gave birth to Kamowakeikazuchi-no-mikoto, he was enshrined by the Kamo territorial ruling family of Anitamayorihiko's descendants.

The ancient text "Yamashiro no Kuni Fudoki" tells that Tamayorihime became pregnant after placing on her bed a vermilion-lacquered arrow that flowed down from the upper reaches of Kamo-gawa River, and that when she gave birth to Kamowakeikazuchi-no-mikoto, he was enshrined by the Kamo territorial ruling family of Anitamayorihiko's descendants.

sen.j: 丹塗矢の正体は、乙訓神社の火雷神とも大山咋神ともいう。
sen.e: The vermillion arrow is said to be Ho-no-ikazuchi-no-kami (the god of fire and thunder) enshrined in Otokuni-jinja Shrine or Oyamakui-no-kami (the deity of Mount Hiei in Shiga Prefecture).
The vermilion-lacquered arrow is said to be Ho-no-ikazuchi-no-kami (the god of fire and thunder) enshrined in Otokuni-jinja Shrine or Oyamakui-no-kami (the deity of Mount Hiei in Shiga Prefecture).
The vermilion-lacquered arrow is said to be Ho-no-ikazuchi-no-kami (the god of fire and thunder) enshrined in Otokuni-jinja Shrine or Oyamakui-no-kami (the deity of Mount Hiei in Shiga Prefecture).

sen.j: 玉依日売とその父の賀茂建角身命は下鴨神社に祀られている。
sen.e: Tamayorihime and her father Kamotaketsunumi -no-mikoto are enshrined within Shimogamo-jinja Shrine.
Tamayorihime and her father Kamotaketsunumi-no-mikoto are enshrined within Shimogamo-jinja Shrine.
Tamayorihime and her father Kamotaketsunumi-no-mikoto are enshrined within Shimogamo-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 六国史では、文武天皇2年（698年）3月21日、賀茂祭の日の騎射を禁じたという記事が初出で、他にも天平勝宝2年（750年）に御戸代田一町が寄進されるなど、朝廷からの崇敬を受けてきたことがわかる。
sen.e: The first mention in Japan's Six National Histories from March 21st 698 states that horseback archery had been banned on the day of the Kamo Festival and we also know that the shrine was revered by the imperial court with an approximately 2.5 acre field being donated by the emperor in 750.

The first mention in Japan's Six National Histories from March 21, 698 (Emperor Mommu's reign) states that horseback archery had been banned on the day of the Kamo Festival and we also know that the shrine was revered by the Imperial Court with an approximately 2.5 acre field being donated by the Emperor in 750.
sen.cmt: Emperor Mommu's reignを補足。Imperial Courtに修正。
sen.e: The first mention in Japan's Six National Histories from March 21, 698 (Emperor Mommu's reign) states that horseback archery had been banned on the day of the Kamo Festival and we also know that the shrine was revered by the Imperial Court with an approximately 2.5 acre field being donated by the Emperor in 750.

sen.j: 794年の平安京遷都の後は王城鎮護の神社としてより一層の崇敬を受け、大同2年（807年）には最高位である正一位の神階を受け、賀茂祭は勅祭とされた。
sen.e: After the capital was relocated to the city of Heian-Kyo in 794, the shrine became even more highly revered by the imperial court as it fell under the protection of the royal castle and was granted the highest possible status in 807, with the Kamo Festival being held by royal order.
sen.cmt: ・Heian-Kyo: 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: After the capital was relocated to the city of Heian-Kyo in 794, the shrine became even more highly revered by the Imperial Court as a shrine for protection of the Imperial Palace and was granted the highest possible status, 'Sho-Ichii' in 807, with the Kamo Festival being held by royal order.
sen.cmt: Imperial Courtに修正。王城鎮護の神社、とは都を守る神社という意味なので、as a shrine for protection of the Imperial Palaceに訂正。'Sho-Ichii' を補足。
sen.e: After the capital was relocated to the city of Heian-Kyo in 794, the shrine became even more highly revered by the Imperial Court as a shrine for protection of the Imperial Palace and was granted the highest possible status, Shoichii (Senior First Rank) in 807, with the Kamo Festival being held by royal order.
sen.cmt: Sho-Ichii'→"Shoichii (Senior First Rank)"に変更しました。

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳では名神大社に列し、名神祭・月次祭・相嘗祭・新嘗祭の各祭の幣帛に預ると記載されている。
sen.e: The Jimmyocho (register of deities) of the Engishiki law ranks it as a Myojin Taisha (a grand shrine that enshrines a high-ranked deity) and states that it held the Myojin-sai festival, Tsukinami-sai festival, Ainame-sai festival and Niname-sai festival.

The Jimmyocho (register of deities) of the Engishiki law ranks it as a Myojin Taisha (a grand shrine that enshrines a high-ranked deity) and states that received offerings at each festival such as the Myojin-sai festival, Tsukinami-sai festival, Ainame-sai festival and Niname-sai festival.
sen.cmt: 各祭の幣帛に預る、部分を補足。
sen.e: The Jimmyocho (register of deities) of the Engishiki law ranks it as a Myojin Taisha (a grand shrine that enshrines a high-ranked deity) and states that received offerings at each festival such as the Myojin-sai festival, Tsukinami-sai festival, Ainame-sai festival and Niname-sai festival.

sen.j: 弘仁元年（810年）以降約400年にわたって、伊勢神宮の斎宮にならった斎院が置かれ、皇女が斎王として奉仕した。
sen.e: For approximately 400 years from 810, unmarried imperial princesses from Ise Shrine's Saigu village served as Saiin and Saio (priestesses) at the shrine.
sen.cmt: ・Saigu: 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: For approximately 400 years from 810, after the model of Saigu of Ise-jingu Shrine, Saiin was placed and unmarried imperial princesses served as Saio (priestesses) at the shrine.
sen.cmt: 伊勢神宮→Ise-jingu Shrine※斎宮は伊勢神宮、斎院は賀茂神社にあった斎王(奉仕した未婚の内親王又は女王)の為の御所。英訳を訂正。
sen.e: For approximately 400 years from 810, after the model of Saigu of Ise-jingu Shrine, Saiin was placed and unmarried imperial princesses served as Saio (priestesses) at the shrine.

sen.j: 明治の近代社格制度でも、官幣大社の筆頭という、伊勢神宮の次位の神社とされ、明治16年には勅祭社に定められた。
sen.e: The shrine was the first of the Kanpei Taisha (Great Imperial Shrines) under the Meiji period integrated system of shrine ranks and second only to Ise Shrine, with it becoming a chokusaisha (shrine attended by imperial envoy) in 1883.
sen.cmt: ・integrated system of shrine ranks: http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/entry.php?entryID=738・chokusaisha (the shrine attended by imperial envoy): http://nippon-kichi.jp/article_list.do;jsessionid=EC7B4A864062CDD2938650C485E4240D?kwd=4764&ml_lang=en
sen.e: The shrine was the first of the Kanpei Taisha (Great Imperial Shrines) under the Meiji period integrated system of shrine ranks and second only to Ise-jingu Shrine, with it becoming a Chokusaisha (shrine attended by imperial envoy) in 1883.
sen.cmt: 伊勢神宮→Ise-jingu ShrineChokusaisha に修正、用語集その他より
sen.e: The shrine was the first of the Kampei Taisha (Great Imperial Shrines) under the Meiji period integrated system of shrine ranks and second only to Ise-jingu Shrine, with it becoming a Chokusaisha (shrine attended by imperial envoy) in 1883.

sen.j: 立砂 - 細殿前の円錐状の二つの砂の山は御神体である神山を模したものであり立砂（たてずな）という。
sen.e: Tatezuna: The two cone-shaped sand mounds in front of the hosodono worship hall represent Mt. Ko-yama in which the deity resides.
Tatezuna: The two cone-shaped sand mounds in front of the hosodono worship hall represent Mt. Ko-yama in which the deity resides.
Tatezuna: The two cone-shaped sand mounds in front of the hosodono worship hall represent Mt. Ko-yama in which the deity resides.

sen.j: 鬼門にまく清めの砂の起源とされる。
sen.e: Spreading sand in the unlucky northeast corner is said to purify the area.
Spreading sand in the unlucky northeast corner is said to purify the area.
Tatezuna is said to be the origin of purifying sand to be spread in the unlucky northeast corner.
